linkTarget.anchoringText: The greatest developed reserves are assigned to Urmano-Archinskaya zone (Fig. 1) well studied with exploration drilling, including core sampling and geophysical methods, well logging and well testing. Thematic works in geology research, geochemistry, stress and fractures reconstruction were carried using these data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Location of Urmano-Archinskaya zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of Urmano-Archinskaya zone

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Cross-section of Paleozoic reservoir within Archinskoe oil field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross-section of Paleozoic reservoir within Archinskoe oil field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Pilot production of Archinskoe oil field accounted for these issues. The field was well characterized with 3D seismic with seismic attribute analysis and prediction of seismic attribute "synergetic singularity", or "deconsolidation"; electric and acoustic well imagers (Fig. 3). Pilot production splits up to Paleozoic deposits drilling; upper Jurassic reservoirs development; geological exploration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Archinskoe oil field state of exploration

formatted-caption.caption-text: Archinskoe oil field state of exploration

linkTarget.anchoringText: Reservoir pressure was obtained by well testing in nearby wells of well pad #10 and well 47R, subject to pressure drop by the well drilling time. Water cut was taken as a mean value of actual well performance in oil and water zone, that is, 10%. Well test data show permeability range to be 0.0005-173 mD. The calculation looks to 1.9 mD value, that is equal to mean permeability value for wells drilled within well pad #10 in 2015. The calculation results are shown in Table 2 and Fig. 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Oil flow rate dependence on amount of branches

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil flow rate dependence on amount of branches

linkTarget.anchoringText: A. Mostly all wells intersect some fractures. It is proved by initial high negative skin-factor and clear linear flow in the beginning of tests. It is illustrated by pressure and pressure derivative log-log plot obtained on vertical well (fig. 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: PTA log-log plots of vertical well start up (registered by ESP pressure gauge)

formatted-caption.caption-text: PTA log-log plots of vertical well start up (registered by ESP pressure gauge)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Almost all wells show infinite-acting radial flow (IARF). It essentially increases studies' reliability and indicates some heterogeneous porous-vuggy media or pseudo-heterogeneous micro-fracture system, which provide IARF to well. Both Figures 5 & 6 show quite evident IARF. This fact is not strong enough to settle type №2 reservoir finally but is enough to exclude type №4 with non-active matrix.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Unsatisfactory matching using horizontal well model with giant vertical permeability and satisfactory match with horizontal fractured well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Unsatisfactory matching using horizontal well model with giant vertical permeability and satisfactory match with horizontal fractured well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Two vertical wells demonstrate composite layer behavior. Log-log plots look like anomalous high skin-factor (fig.7) but it is to be interpreted as radial composite layer with much more better properties (more fractures) in 100 meters range (fixed IARF). Acid frac job was conducted on well№1 and liquid rate increased in several times with 20% water cut growth.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Behavior of wells drilled in low permeable zones, interpreted with radial composite model instead of giant skin-factor

formatted-caption.caption-text: Behavior of wells drilled in low permeable zones, interpreted with radial composite model instead of giant skin-factor

linkTarget.anchoringText: Almost all wells show infinite-acting radial flow (IARF). It essentially increases studies' reliability and indicates some heterogeneous porous-vuggy media or pseudo-heterogeneous micro-fracture system, which provide IARF to well. Both Figures 5 & 6 show quite evident IARF. This fact is not strong enough to settle type №2 reservoir finally but is enough to exclude type №4 with non-active matrix.

Log-log plots look like anomalous high skin-factor (fig.7) but it is to be interpreted as radial composite layer with much more better properties (more fractures) in 100 meters range (fixed IARF). image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Loss of return probability dependence on seismic attributes

formatted-caption.caption-text: Loss of return probability dependence on seismic attributes

linkTarget.anchoringText: Paleozoic geological features within Urmano-Archinskaya zone are determined by massive carbonate deposits with well-developed tectonics, reservoir vugs, pores and fractures storativity and conductivity, as well as gas cap and bottom water influence (Figure 2). The formation is divided into M layer – residual soil consisting of aluminic bauxite-like rocks, and M1 layer - Paleozoice carbonate rocks itself made up of biogenic limestone within Urmanskoe oil field and shallow water shoal facies on Archinskoe oil field, as it has been discovered during palaeo-facial reconstruction (Appendix A-1).

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-1
image-wrap.caption: Palaeo-facial reconstruction of Paleozoic deposits within Urmano-Archinskaya zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Palaeo-facial reconstruction of Paleozoic deposits within Urmano-Archinskaya zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Drilling of Urmanskoe oil field met many drilling problems: oil and gas shows, catastrophic losses of mud return, drill pipe drag and sticking, rock sloughing and well collapse. Urmanskoe and Archinskoe oil fields were drilled with bit set on casing to prevent these failures (Appendix A-2). Drilling-with-casing reduces amount of wells abandoned while drilling significantly, as well as enables underbalanced drilling with full geosteering.

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-2
image-wrap.caption: Equipment arrangement for drilling-with-casing.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Equipment arrangement for drilling-with-casing.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Place for "Fishbone" multilateral well drilling was chosen outside the gas cap and within sufficient net pay thickness zone. The area is surrounded by wells with proven efficiency (Appendix A-3).

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-3
image-wrap.caption: Fragment of oil net pay map and M1 top structure map of Archinskoe oil field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fragment of oil net pay map and M1 top structure map of Archinskoe oil field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The approximate multilateral well drilling diagram is shown in Appendix A-4 (a). Appendix A-4 (b) shows generic completion scheme for the multilateral well. The feature of this technology is possibility for selective treatment and isolation of every branch without entrance.

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-4
image-wrap.caption: a. Branch drilling process. b. Generic well completion scheme. c. Equipment with "Harrier tool" arrangement.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Appendix A-4 a. Branch drilling process. b. Generic well completion scheme. c. Equipment with "Harrier tool" arrangement.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Then the equal probability of both events was assumed: "branch faces a fracture" probability is 50%and "branch faces no fractures" is 50%, too (actually the probability of fracture facing is about 88% for wells within well pad #10). Expected value of well flow rate was calculated by weighing the probabilities of fracture facing by each amount of braches (Appendix A-5) for this reason.

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-5
image-wrap.caption: Efficiency probability and working branches amount

formatted-caption.caption-text: Efficiency probability and working branches amount

linkTarget.anchoringText: The field is explored with high-quality 3D seismic with attribute analysis and fracture zones prediction (Appendix A-6), as well as fractures were studied using FMI imagers in wells (Appendix A-7).

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-6
image-wrap.caption: Fractures associated seismic attributes.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fractures associated seismic attributes.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The field is explored with high-quality 3D seismic with attribute analysis and fracture zones prediction (Appendix A-6), as well as fractures were studied using FMI imagers in wells (Appendix A-7).

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-7
image-wrap.caption: State of field exploration by FMI.

formatted-caption.caption-text: State of field exploration by FMI.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Maximum liquid flow rate (usually represented by initial well flow rate) showed negligibly small correlation with seismic attributes (Appendix A-8) like acoustic impedance, RMS amplitude, attenuation frequency and "deconsolidation" attribute.

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-8
image-wrap.caption: Maximum liquid flow rate dependence on seismic attributes averaged on wellbore length.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maximum liquid flow rate dependence on seismic attributes averaged on wellbore length.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Similar correlation of maximum liquid flow rate and mean azimuth difference, mean dip angle difference, depth under M1 top and mud loss rate (Appendix A-9) revealed weak interconnection of these parameters.

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-9
image-wrap.caption: Maximum liquid flow rate dependence on technological well properties averaged on wellbore length (mud loss rate, m3/hr; depth under M1 top, m; difference between directional well angle and formation dip angle, degrees; difference between well azimuth and formation azimuth, degrees)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maximum liquid flow rate dependence on technological well properties averaged on wellbore length (mud loss rate, m3/hr; depth under M1 top, m; difference between directional well angle and formation dip angle, degrees; difference between well azimuth and formation azimuth, degrees)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Cross-reference of mud loss rate (Appendix A-10) and seismic attributes confidently selects attenuation frequency parameter. It does not allow predicting loss of return fact, but certainly indicates mud loss rate increase (in logarithmic scale) with this parameter growth.

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-10
image-wrap.caption: Mud loss rate dependence on seismic attributes.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mud loss rate dependence on seismic attributes.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Prediction of the mud loss rate using various technological and geometrical parameters (Appendix A-11) shows that the depth under M1 top is the most representative parameter. But this fact is associated again with analyzed data selection, namely, horizontal well configuration strategy.

image-wrap.label: Appendix A-11
image-wrap.caption: Mud loss rate dependence on technological well properties (depth under M1 top, m; difference between directional well angle and formation dip angle, degrees; difference between well azimuth and formation azimuth, degrees)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mud loss rate dependence on technological well properties (depth under M1 top, m; difference between directional well angle and formation dip angle, degrees; difference between well azimuth and formation azimuth, degrees)
